The most common routes of transmission include direct contact with infected animal tissues (especially the placenta), consumption of unpasteurized dairy products, and inhalation of aerosols. Person to person transmission of brucellosis is extremely rare and not typically included as a major route of transmission in educational or preventive strategies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Contact with infected placenta is a well-documented route of Brucella transmission among veterinary workers and those involved in animal husbandry.

 

Option B. Ingestion of raw vegetables contaminated with Brucella from infected farm soil or water can be a potential route of transmission, though less common than others.

 

Option D. Inhalation of infected dust or aerosol is a recognized occupational hazard in meatpacking and other industries involving animal products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Person to person transmission of brucellosis is not a typical mode of transmission and is very rare compared to other routes such as contact with infected animals, consumption of unpasteurized dairy products, and inhalation of aerosols.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p357, 2/e p374, Ananthanarayan 9/e p342, 10/e p346-347, Harrison, 20/e p1194-95

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his genitalia. He has no significant medical history and reports unprotected sexual contact. Physical examination reveals a clean base, non-exudative ulcer, and non-palpable inguinal lymph nodes. A darkfield microscopy examination of the ulcer exudate is performed. Which one of the following organisms, if seen under darkfield microscopy, would confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pallidum

 

Option A:

 

Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, can be visualized using darkfield microscopy, which allows for the observation of live organisms and their characteristic motility. The presence of T. pallidum in ulcer exudate is diagnostic of syphilis, correlating with the clinical presentation of a painless genital ulcer, which is typical for primary syphilis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which presents as a painful ulcer and is not visualized on darkfield microscopy.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex virus causes painful genital ulcers and is diagnosed with Tzanck smear or PCR, not darkfield microscopy.

 

Option D. Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, presenting with beefy red ulcers and is diagnosed with Donovan bodies on tissue smear, not darkfield microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treponema pallidum can be visualized using darkfield microscopy. The presence of T. pallidum in genital ulcer exudate is diagnostic of syphilis. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1e/p372, 2/e p387

choices.text: Treponemal pallidum particle agglutination assay (TP-PA)
Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) test
Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a maculopapular rash and a low-grade fever. She is 24 weeks pregnant and concerned about her unborn child. She mentions her partner was recently diagnosed with an STI. Examination reveals a widespread rash including the palms and soles, and condyloma lata. She denies any genital ulcers. What is the most appropriate initial screening test to perform in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VDRL (Veneral disease reasearch laboratory)

 

Option A:

 

VDRL is a non-treponemal serologic test commonly used for the initial screening of syphilis. It is relatively inexpensive, widely available, and provides rapid results. It is sensitive in the detection of secondary syphilis, which the patient is likely to have given her symptoms of a rash including palms and soles, condyloma lata, and a recent partner diagnosis of an STI.

 

RPR could also be given and can be marked if VDRL was not given.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The TP-PA (Treponemma pallidum particle agglutination test) is a treponemal test used for confirmation after a positive non-treponemal test rather than for initial screening.

 

Option C. The FTA-ABS (Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test) test is also a confirmatory treponemal test that remains positive for life and is not typically used for initial screening.

 

Option D. The HSV PCR test is used to diagnose herpes simplex virus infections, not syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RPR test as the appropriate initial screening tool for a pregnant woman with signs suggestive of secondary syphilis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p375, 2/e p391

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high fever, headache, and a rash that started on his trunk and spread peripherally. He recently returned from a camping trip. He is sexually active with one partner and uses condoms consistently. On examination, the rash spares his face and is notable for its centripetal spread. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rocky Mountain spotted fever

 

Option A:

 

Rocky Mountain spotted fever, caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, typically presents with fever, headache, and a centripetal rash that often involves the palms and soles. The patient's recent camping trip suggests a tick exposure, which is consistent with the epidemiology of this disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Secondary syphilis could present with similar symptoms but the rash of secondary syphilis also typically involves the palms and soles and is associated with sexual contact.

 

Option C. Lyme disease presents with erythema migrans, which is typically a single, expanding rash, not a centripetal rash.

 

Option D. Measles presents with a rash that spreads from the face downward and is preceded by cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis (the 3 Cs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rocky Mountain spotted fever - Caused by Rickettsia rickettsii.

 

  • Transmission:  By the bite of an infected tick
  • Reservoir:  Ticks serve as vector as well as reservoir. Other mammals like dogs, small rodents can also act as reservoir
  • Clinical manifestations:  IP 4 to 14 days
    • An acute potentially fatal disease characterized by fever, headache, rash, myalgia and anorexia
    • Rashes appear typically on extremities (wrist and ankles) and trunk. Initially they are maculopapular, later become hemorrhagic

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p389, 2/e p404, Harrison 19/e p1155-59, 20/e p1304

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a painful swelling in his right groin area. On physical examination, a bulge is noted at the mid inguinal point, which is located midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis. This finding is most suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect Inguinal Hernia

 

Option B: Indirect Inguinal Hernia is the most common type of hernia in both men and women. It protrudes at the mid inguinal point, which is a landmark used to distinguish between direct and indirect inguinal hernias.

 

The indirect inguinal hernia lies lateral to inferior epigastric vessels hence the bulging is seen at the level of midinguinal point.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Femoral Hernia: Typically appears below the inguinal ligament, more common in women. The location described in the question does not correspond to the typical site of a femoral hernia.

 

Option C. Direct Inguinal Hernia: Occurs medially to the inferior epigastric vessels and typically presents in older men. It protrudes through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, which is not at the mid inguinal point.

 

Option D. Spigelian Hernia: Occurs along the spigelian fascia, which is found lateral to the rectus abdominis muscles. This is not consistent with the location described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Indirect Inguinal Hernia is the most common type of hernia in both men and women. It protrudes at the mid inguinal point, which is a landmark used to distinguish between direct and indirect inguinal hernias.
  • This type of hernia follows the path of the inguinal canal and often protrudes into the scrotum in men.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, pg. 55
